bestBHT.bht: The reputation of Jesus was causing concern to Herod, who had executed John the Baptist. Herod sought to see Jesus, but he did not have the opportunity until Jesus was brought before him as a prisoner. This desire to see Jesus was persistent, as Herod kept on seeking to see him. The rumors of Jesus' works and teachings disturbed Herod, who feared that perhaps Jesus was John the Baptist raised from the dead. This incident with Herod wanting to see Jesus sets the stage for the subsequent events of Jesus miraculously feeding the five thousand.

Henry Alford: 9.] The repetition of “I” (which is emphatic in the original) implies personal concern and alarm at the growing fame of Jesus: see notes on Matthew.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: desired to see him—but did not.
till as a prisoner He was sent to him by Pilate just before His death.
ON THE RETURN OF THE TWELVE JESUS RETIRES WITH THEM TO BETHSAIDA, AND THERE MIRACULOUSLY FEEDS FIVE THOUSAND.
Marvin Vincent: He desired [εζητει] . Rev., he sought. He did more than desire.
Archibald T. Robertson: He sought (εζητε). Imperfect active. He keep on seeking to see Jesus.
The rumours disturbed Herod because he was sure that he had put him to death.
John Gill: I have beheaded him! and yet who should it be?
he began to fear that it was he

bhtAttempts.bht: The reputation of Jesus was causing concern to Herod, who had executed John the Baptist. Herod sought to see Jesus, but he did not have the opportunity until Jesus was brought before him as a prisoner. This desire to see Jesus was persistent, as Herod kept on seeking to see him. The rumors of Jesus' works and teachings disturbed Herod, who feared that perhaps Jesus was John the Baptist raised from the dead. This incident with Herod wanting to see Jesus sets the stage for the subsequent events of Jesus miraculously feeding the five thousand.

The growing fame of Jesus disturbed Herod, who had previously beheaded John the Baptist. Herod's desire to see Jesus persisted, leading him to seek an encounter with him. This desire was eventually fulfilled when Jesus was brought before him as a prisoner. Herod's fear and speculation about Jesus being John the Baptist raised from the dead added to the intrigue surrounding Jesus. This desire to see Jesus serves as a backdrop to the subsequent miraculous feeding of the five thousand.

Disturbed by the growing fame of Jesus, Herod sought to see him, persistently seeking an encounter with the renowned teacher. These efforts were finally realized when Jesus was brought before Herod as a prisoner. The rumors and speculation surrounding Jesus made Herod fearful, as he wondered if perhaps Jesus was John the Baptist resurrected. This curiosity and desire to see Jesus set the stage for the miraculous feeding of the five thousand, illustrating the impact Jesus had on those who sought him.

Disturbed by the growing fame of Jesus, Herod sought to see him, persistently seeking an encounter with the renowned teacher. These efforts were finally realized when Jesus was brought before Herod as a prisoner. The rumors and speculation surrounding Jesus made Herod fearful, as he wondered if perhaps Jesus was John the Baptist resurrected. This curiosity and desire to see Jesus set the stage for the subsequent events, including the miraculous feeding of the five thousand, showcasing the transformative power of Jesus' ministry.

Herod, disturbed by the growing fame of Jesus, persistently sought to see him. This desire was eventually fulfilled when Jesus was brought before Herod as a prisoner. The rumors and speculation surrounding Jesus made Herod fearful, wondering if Jesus was John the Baptist resurrected. This curiosity and longing to see Jesus prompted by Herod set the stage for the subsequent events, such as the miraculous feeding of the five thousand, demonstrating the profound impact and influence of Jesus' ministry.
